original_content:
There is a big difference between building one of something and building, say, 100 of the same item. It isnt surprising, then, that 3D printing in bulk differs from printing one object at a time. Of course, filling up your build plate is not a new idea. But [Keep Making] wants to encourage you to think in three dimensions and fill up your build volume in the Z axis, as well.
When you fill your X and Y axes, it is easy to see how the parts separate. But with stack printing, you must separate the parts from different layers. Each part has a single-layer gap, and the top surfaces are ironed for a better finish. Sometimes the prints may stick, and the video shows how to use a screw to pop off recalcitrant prints. The technique produces one side that isnt as nice a finish as the other side, but it isnt bad, and for many applications, you dont care, anyway.
Before you get too excited about your own designs, you might try a simple test file and get your print settings dialed in. Obviously, if you need just two or three copies of something small, it is easier to step and repeat them across the build surface. But if you need to maximize your throughput or make multiple copies of large objects, this might be the technique for you.
Looks like an interesting technique that doesnt require you to do anything strange like, say, waterproof your printer. No strings attached.
title: 3Dプリントで一度に複数のオブジェクトを作製する方法
body: 3Dプリント技術で効率的に物を作る方法が紹介されている。レイヤーごとのパーツとして作成し、別々に分離する。表面の仕上げは一部に問題があるが、多くの場合は問題ない。多量の物を作るには有効な方法。
titles: 3Dプリントで一度に複数のオブジェクトを作製する方法
Z軸を使って3Dプリントのボリュームを最大限に活用する方法
スタックプリントを使ったボリューム作製のテクニック
大量のオブジェクトを効率的に作製するためのヒント
3Dプリントで多数の大きなオブジェクトを短時間で作製する方法
